full_text: In this demonstration, I'll show how BillingCenter charges an invoice fee according to the Accounts Billing Plan. Here is the Account Summary screen for the Lauren Ramirez account. To find the Accounts Billing Plan, we'll go to the Account Details. I'll click BP02 to go to the plan. Notice the plan specifies a $2 invoice fee. Let's return to the Account Details screen. Next, I'll go to the Invoices tab. I can see the first invoice is for $410. The bill date is today, so no need to advance the clock. Let's switch to Super User to run the invoice batch process. Here's the invoice batch process. I click Run. Now let's return to Jeff Park. To refresh the screen, I click on the Next Invoice. Notice the first invoice is now billed. Let's look at the invoice items for the first invoice. Here's the one-time fee in the amount of $2. The invoice fee charge was added by the invoice batch process. Let's look at the first planned invoice. This invoice only has a premium item of $123 and no invoice fee item. Why is there no invoice fee on the planned invoice? The answer is, invoice fees are created by the invoice batch process only when it changes the invoice status from plan to build. Now let's look at the payment requests screen. I click the menu icon for payments in the sidebar. Now I click Payment Requests. As we know, this account has a non-responsive payment instrument. Here's the payment request. The invoice batch process created the payment request on the invoice bill date. Notice the status is created and the request date is tomorrow. Let's return to Super User to advance the clock by a day and run a batch process. We first go to Internal Tools. Here's the testing system clock menu item. I click Add Day. The clock has been advanced by a day. Now we'll go to Server Tools. Here's the payment request batch process, which I'll run now. Let's return to Jeff Park to see what's happened to our payment request. First, I refresh the screen by clicking to another screen. And now I return to Payment Requests. Notice the status of the payment request has changed to Requested. As time advances and the other payment request dates are reached, the payment request batch process will update the payment request statuses accordingly. This concludes our demonstration on invoice fees and payment requests.

segments.text: In this demonstration, I'll show how BillingCenter charges an invoice fee according to the Accounts Billing Plan. Here is the Account Summary screen for the Lauren Ramirez account. To find the Accounts Billing Plan, we'll go to the Account Details. I'll click BP02 to go to the plan. Notice the plan specifies a $2 invoice fee. Let's return to the Account Details screen. Next, I'll go to the Invoices tab.

I can see the first invoice is for $410. The bill date is today, so no need to advance the clock. Let's switch to Super User to run the invoice batch process. Here's the invoice batch process. I click Run. Now let's return to Jeff Park. To refresh the screen, I click on the Next Invoice. Notice the first invoice is now billed. Let's look at the invoice items for the first invoice.
Here's the one-time fee in the amount of $2. The invoice fee charge was added by the invoice batch process. Let's look at the first planned invoice.

This invoice only has a premium item of $123 and no invoice fee item. Why is there no invoice fee on the planned invoice? The answer is, invoice fees are created by the invoice batch process only when it changes the invoice status from plan to build.
Now let's look at the payment requests screen. I click the menu icon for payments in the sidebar.

Now I click Payment Requests. As we know, this account has a non-responsive payment instrument. Here's the payment request. The invoice batch process created the payment request on the invoice bill date. Notice the status is created and the request date is tomorrow. Let's return to Super User to advance the clock by

a day and run a batch process. We first go to Internal Tools. Here's the testing system clock menu item. I click Add Day. The clock has been advanced by a day. Now we'll go to Server Tools. Here's the payment request batch process, which I'll run now. Let's return to Jeff Park to see what's happened to our payment request.

First, I refresh the screen by clicking to another screen. And now I return to Payment Requests. Notice the status of the payment request has changed to Requested. As time advances and the other payment request dates are reached, the payment request batch process will update the payment request statuses accordingly. This concludes our demonstration on invoice fees and payment requests.
